questions.text: A patient is comfortable at rest but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitations and dyspnoea. His NYHA grade is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

NYHA classification is as follows-

Class I-No symptoms of heart failure, and no limitation on ordinary physical activity

Class II-Mild symptoms, such as shortness of breath or angina, and limitation during ordinary activity

Class III-Marked limitation in activity due to symptoms, even during less-than-ordinary activity

Class IV-Severe limitations, and symptoms even while at rest

questions.text: Faget sign is seen which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The causes of Faget sign or relative bradycardia are as follows:

1.	Yellow fever.

2.	Typhoid fever.

3.	Brain abscess.

4.	Tularaemia.

5.	Brucellosis.

6.	Colorado tick fever.

7.	Legionella pneumonia 

8.	Drug fever

questions.text: A patient has two peaks of pulse in systole. Most likely cause is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Two peaks in systole is known as Bisferiens pulse seen in severe AR, Severe AR with AS and HOCM.

questions.text: On physical examination, you observe a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse. Which of the following is NOT the cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Large a wave is seen in- 

1.	Tricuspid stenosis: This condition results in obstruction at the tricuspid valve, preventing normal blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle, thus causing a large 'a' wave.

2.	Right ventricular hypertrophy or pulmonary hypertension: These conditions increase resistance in the right ventricle, leading to a large 'a' wave.AF has absence of a wave

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with fatigue, abdominal swelling, and peripheral edema. On physical examination, her jugular venous pressure increases with inspiration. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Kussmaul's sign is an increase in jugular venous pressure (JVP) on inspiration. Conditions associated with Kussmaul's sign include:

1.	Constrictive pericarditis: This condition involves a thickened, non-compliant pericardium that restricts diastolic filling of the heart, causing JVP to increase with inspiration.

2.	Right ventricular infarction: Similar to constrictive pericarditis, it affects right ventricular filling.

3.	Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This condition causes the myocardium to become rigid, impairing diastolic filling.

questions.text: A 25 year old female with hypertension presents with seizures. BP on admission is 220/120 mm Hg. What will be the best management for her
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In hypertensive emergency, here hypertensive encephalopathy/eclampsia is present.It is treated with iv labetolol.NTG is given if MI is present.

questions.text: A 25 year old female with hypertension presents with seizures. BP on admission is 220/120 mm Hg. What will be the best management for her
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In hypertensive emergency, here hypertensive encephalopathy/eclampsia is present.It is treated with iv labetolol.NTG is given if MI is present.

questions.text: Identify the wrong auscultatory cardiac area marked in the figure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Area marked as 2 is pulmonary area. Erb’s area is no. 3.

questions.text: Causes of soft S1 heart sound includes all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

All valvular heart diseases cause soft S1 except MS and TS. Other causes of soft S1 include- LVF,RVF, bradycardia and prolong PR interval.

questions.text: A patient has wide split of S2 heart sound. The likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pulmonary stenosis leads to late P2 sound making S2 wide split.LBBB,AS and LVF causes late A2 making S2 reverse split.

questions.text: An old man presents with complaints of palpitations. General physical examination shows bisferiens pulse. On auscultation early diastolic murmur is heard at Erb’s area. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Early diastolic murmur is due to aortic insufficiency (Erb’s area) and pulmonary insufficiency (pulmonary area).Mitral and tricuspid insufficiency cause pan systolic murmur.

questions.text: Identify the cause of this murmur heart at 2nd right intercostal space
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aortic stenosis typically presents with a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotid arteries due to turbulent blood flow across the narrowed aortic valve during systole. This murmur is often described as having a "diamond-shaped" configuration.

questions.text: A 14 year old boy resident of Delhi slum area, c/o sore throat followed by pain and redness of multiple large joints. On examination temperature is 38.3 C, heart rate 110/min and a skin rash as shown in the figure. How many Jones criteria are present
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Polyarthirits and erythema marginatum are major criteria.Fever more than 38 C is minor criteria.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with RHD and severe mitral stenosis comes for a routine health check up. She is asymptomatic. On examination: PR- 70/min regular and normal JVP. There are no lung crepts. Which of the following is the most appropriate next recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Patient is asymptomatic hence no need for surgery or diuretics. Penicillin prophylaxis is needed lifelong.

choices.text: Observation with regular follow-up and echocardiography
Initiation of medical therapy with diuretic

questions.text: A 65-year-old asymptomatic male is found to have severe chronic mitral regurgitation incidentally on routine echocardiography. He denies any symptoms such as dyspnea, palpitations, or chest pain. There are no signs of heart failure. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In asymptomatic patients with severe chronic mitral regurgitation, the management approach depends on the presence or absence of symptoms and the presence of left ventricular dysfunction or significant left ventricular dilation. As this patient is asymptomatic with no signs of heart failure, the appropriate management strategy is observation with regular follow-up and echocardiography.

choices.text: More commonly seen in males than females

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mitral valve prolapse is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mitral valve prolapse is a common valvular abnormality characterized by the displacement of mitral valve leaflets into the left atrium during systole. It is more commonly seen in females, particularly in young women. MVP is typically associated with a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur, not a crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: Carvallo sign is seen in which valvular heart disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pan systolic murmur in TR which increases on inspiration is known as Carvallo sign.

questions.text: What will be the most likely micro-organism responsible for infective endocarditis in iv drug abuse
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In IV drug abuse the most common organism is staphylococcus aureus but mainly affecting tricuspid valve. Left sided infective endocarditis is most commonly due to Enterococci.

questions.text: Which of the following is reversible form of dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The causes of reversible form of DCMP are 

•	Alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy 

•	Peri-partum cardiomyopathy

•	Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

•	Deficiency state induced

•	Chronic uncontrolled tachycardia

questions.text: A 25 year old had sudden cardiac death while playing football. Heart Autopsy revealed findings as shown in the figure. Which of the following statements regarding this heart condition is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

HOCM is characterized by hypertrophy of the left ventricular myocardium, leading to a decrease in the size of the left ventricular chamber rather than dilation. HOCM is typically caused by mutations in genes encoding sarcomere proteins, such as beta-myosin heavy chain (MYH7) and cardiac myosin-binding protein C (MYBPC3). These mutations lead to asymmetric hypertrophy of the myocardium and impaired diastolic filling.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is suggestive of heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Heart failure is characterized by the inability of the heart to pump blood efficiently, leading to symptoms of congestion and low perfusion. The clinical presentation of heart failure can vary widely but often includes symptoms such as dyspnoea, PND, orthopnoea, and lower extremity edema. JVP is increased. BNP levels are elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy for patient with acute decompensated heart failure and pulmonary edema?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The initial management of acute decompensated heart failure focuses on oxygen followed by reducing volume overload and relieving symptoms of congestion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dyspnea on exertion. On examination, it is noted that the JVP rises during inspiration. A chest radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

JVP rises during inspiration is seen in constrictive pericarditis.Chest x ray shows calcified pericardium.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complaints of acute dyspnea. BP is 80/60 mmHg, neck veins are prominent and heart sounds are soft. What is the likely cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Patient has Beck’s triad- low BP, distended neck veins and soft heart sounds seen in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 35 year old male, smoker, presented with anginal chest pain. The ECG was done which shows ST elevation in anterior chest wall leads. Troponin done twice at 6 hrs interval was negative. Which drug not given in this case
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The diagnosis here is Prinzmetal (variant) angina as troponin levels are not raised. Aspirin and beta blocker should be avoided as these agents can precipitate coronary vasospasm.

questions.text: In a patient with NSTEMI, all the following can be used for treatment except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In NSTEMI thrombolytic are contraindicated. Antiplatelets,nitrates,heparin and betablockers are standard conservative treatment for NSTEMI.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with sudden onset chest pain. An ECG was performed which is shown in the image. What would be most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ST elevation is seen in II,III and aVF which indicates inferior wall MI. V3-4 represents anterior wall, posterior wall ST elevation is seen in V7-9.In acute pericarditis ST elevation is diffuse.

questions.text: Following the diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction what is the most appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Primary percutaneous coronary intervention is the preferred reperfusion strategy in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction if it can be performed in a timely manner by an experienced team. PCI involves the mechanical restoration of coronary blood flow by percutaneous balloon angioplasty and stent placement. It is associated with better outcomes, including lower mortality rates and reduced risk of recurrent myocardial infarction, compared to fibrinolytic therapy.

questions.text: Calculate the heart rate in the given ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HR=1500/RR interval. RR interval is 10 mm

questions.text: Identify the cause of these ECG changes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 rSR’ pattern is seen in V1 suggestive of RBBB. RVH will show tall R in V1,LVH tall R in V6.LBBB has M pattern in V6.

questions.text: A patient complains of palpitations. On examination, irregularly irregular radial pulse is present, and ECG shows absent P wave. Which of the following condition is likely present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Absent P wave with irregular rhythm is atrial fibrillation, with regular rhythm it will be PSVT.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with 30 minutes of palpitations. Her symptoms began abruptly. A physical examination reveals a tachycardia, regular heart rhythm and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg. An ECG is shown in Figure. Carotid sinus pressure fails to terminate the arrhythmia. The next best step in management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This is PSVT (absent P waves with narrow QRS complex).Patient is stable-first line is carotid massage and if no response then iv adenosine is given.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male has monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. The patient is hemodynamically stable. What is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient's monomorphic ventricular tachycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In patients with stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia , the initial management approach involves the administration of antiarrhythmic medication to terminate the arrhythmia. Options for antiarrhythmic medications include intravenous lidocaine, amiodarone, or procainamide. These medications help to stabilize the myocardium and terminate the ventricular tachycardia. Electrical cardioversion is reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients with VT or patients with VT refractory to pharmacological therapy. Adenosine is not effective for terminating ventricular tachycardia and is contraindicated in this scenario.

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is Torsades de pointes,It is precipitated by hypomagnesemia,hypocalcemia and rarely hypokalemia.

questions.text: A young patient complains of fatigue and recurrent syncopal episodes. Severe bradycardia was noted on a 24-hour Holter monitoring. What would be the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Severe symptomatic bradycardia is treated with artificial pacemaker. ICD is given for arrythmia which causes increased risk of sudden cardiac death like HOCM.

questions.text: What would be next step in management of the condition shown in the figure:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The given ECG showed ventricular fibrillation.Next step is defibrillation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to the ER. On ECG, a wide QRS complex and tall T waves were seen. Identify the possible cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hyperkalemia leads to tall T waves,small P waves and wide QRS complex.Hypokalemia causes small T waves with prominent U waves.Sodium abnormalities will not affect ECG.

questions.text: All the following ECG changes are due to digoxin except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Digoxin causes all type of AV block except Mobitz type II second degree AV block.Other ECG changes are ventricular ectopics,bigeminy rhythm and bidirectional ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: Patient came in with the history of regurgitation and chest pain. Barium swallow image is given here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Barium swallow shows cork screw pattern suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm. Achalasia shows beak pattern.

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient with HIV infection complains of odynophagia. Endoscopy reveals normal esophageal mucosa with serpiginous ulcer in distal part. What is the most likely etiology of this esophageal disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serpiginous ulcer is due to CMV. Herpes causes Volcano like ulcer and white friable plagues seen in candida infection.

questions.text: The quadruple therapy regime (or OBMT regime) for Helicobacter Pylori eradication comprises which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Indication of H Pylori eradication are peptic ulcer and MALT lymphoma. Four drug therapy omeprazole, bismuth, metronidazole and tetracycline is given for 2 weeks

questions.text: A 55‐year‐old man has progressive difficulty standing upright, walking, and raising himself out of a chair followed by difficulty in raising arm. He had an episode of diarrhea 4 weeks earlier. Which of the following infectious agents is most likely cause in the differential diagnoses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This is a clinical case of GBS post infection (campylobacter jejuni).E coli leads to reactive arthritis, Clostridium difficile is post antibiotics and Shigella causes HUS.

questions.text: A 65‐year‐old man presents with fever and diarrhea of 3 days duration. He recently completed a course of cephalosporin for otitis media. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s diarrhea and preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antibiotic use is associated with clostridium difficile. Presently DOC is fidaxomicin.

questions.text: A female patient with celiac disease is recommended a gluten-free diet. Which among the following can she consume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Celiac disease patient should take gluten free diet like rice, potato and corn.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presented with chronic diarrhoea without blood in stools and migratory polyarthritis. Small intestinal biopsy reveals PAS positive macrophages containing bacilli which are non-AFB. The most likely cause is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Most common extraintestinal manifestation in Whipple disease is arthritis.SI biopsy will show PAS positive macrophage containing non-AFB bacilli. Intestinal TB will have AFB positive bacilli. IBD like UC and CD have blood in stools.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female c/o diarrhoea for last 6 months. She was taking the oral contraceptive pill and smoked 10 cigarettes per day. Anti-Endomysial antibody negative. Biopsies from the terminal ileum showed chronic inflammation with ulceration and non-caseating granulomas. The most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oral contraceptive pills and smoking increases the risk for Crohn’s disease. Non caseating granuloma further support the diagnosis. Ulcerative colitis doesn’t involve ileum.

choices.text: Ulcerative colitis primarily affects the small intestine and is associated with skip lesions.
Ulcerative colitis is characterized by transmural inflammation of the intestinal wall and can lead to the formation of fistulas and strictures.
Ulcerative colitis typically presents with rectal bleeding and is associated with continuous inflammation limited to the colon and rectum.
Ulcerative colitis is often associated with the presence of granulomas on histopathological examination of intestinal biopsies.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ulcerative colitis primarily affects the colon and rectum, not the small intestine, and is characterized by continuous inflammation without skip lesions. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by mucosal inflammation limited to the colon and rectum, without involvement of the full thickness of the intestinal wall. Complications such as fistulas and strictures are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease, which can involve the entire thickness of the intestinal wall. Ulcerative colitis typically presents with symptoms such as rectal bleeding, diarrhea (often bloody), and abdominal pain. The inflammation in ulcerative colitis is continuous and limited to the colon and rectum, without involvement of the small intestine. Granulomas are more commonly seen in Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to with complaints of yellow discoloration of eyes for the past week. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin, with normal liver enzymes and no evidence of hemolysis on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following disorders is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, inherited disorder characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 1A1 (UGT1A1), which conjugates bilirubin in the liver. The elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels in Gilbert syndrome are typically less than 5 mg/dL and are often exacerbated by fasting, illness, or stress. Patients with Gilbert syndrome are otherwise healthy and do not have evidence of liver disease or hemolysis. Dubin-Johnson syndrome is autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin, leading to the accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in hepatocytes and subsequent jaundice. 
Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severely impaired or absent activity of UGT1A1, leading to markedly elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels and the risk of bilirubin encephalopathy. Crigler-Najjar syndrome is typically diagnosed in infancy or childhood and requires lifelong treatment with phototherapy or liver transplantation.

questions.text: A young woman complains of 1 week of fatigue, change in skin colour, and dark brown urine. She has right upper quadrant tenderness and ALT of 1000 U/L, serum Bilirubin is 15 mg/dL (12 mg/dL direct-reacting), and the alkaline phosphatase is normal. What is the most likely cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Elevation of direct bilirubin is seen in hepatitis and obstructive jaundice. ALT is high in hepatitis and ALP raised in obstructive jaundice due to pancreatic carcinoma.

questions.text: Which one of the following viruses associated with development of fulminant hepatitis and high mortality in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatitis E becomes more fulminant in pregnancy with a risk of 10-20%.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following reports: HbsAg-reactive, Anti Hbs-negative, Anti Hbc-IgG positive. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Presence of HbsAg with IgG anti Hbc indicates chronic infection.In acute HbsAg with IgM anti Hbc will be positive.Window period has only IgM anti Hbc.

choices.text: Hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immune globulin

questions.text: A healthcare worker (whose vaccination status is not known) accidentally sustains a needlestick injury while performing a procedure on a patient known to be positive for hepatitis B surface antigen. Which of the following is the most appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


The most appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen for hepatitis B virus (HBV) after percutaneous exposure to HBsAg-positive blood or body fluids is administration of both hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG). The combination of vaccine and HBIG provides both active and passive immunity against HBV, reducing the risk of infection following exposure.

choices.text: Initiation of velpatasvir and sofosbuvir for 8 weeks
Initiation of velpatasvir and sofosbuvir for 12 weeks
Initiation of peginterferon alfa and ribavirin for 24 weeks

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient has chronic hepatitis C virus infection. The patient has compensated liver disease with no evidence of cirrhosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The most appropriate management strategy for this patient with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and compensated liver disease is initiation of velpatasvir and sofosbuvir for 12 weeks.  Peginterferon alfa and ribavirin was previously the standard of care for the treatment of chronic HCV infection. However, it has been largely replaced by all-oral direct-acting antiviral regimens.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with intentional tremors, hepatomegaly and CNS changes came to the opd with the following image. Siblings also have the same disease. This is due to the deposition of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The clinical features are suggestive of wilson’s disease.There is copper overload.

questions.text: Which parameter is not included in MELD score
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MELD score is used for liver transplant indication.Parameters used are- INR, serum bilirubin and serum creatinine.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Chronic Liver Disease patient presented to OPD with fever and gross abdominal distention. On abdominal examination, tenderness is elicited. Ascitic fluid reveals the presence of neutrophils of 500/ mm3. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a case of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis as evident by neutrophil in ascites fluid > 250/mm3 . Treatment consists of antibiotics.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis secondary to alcoholic liver disease presents to the emergency department with confusion and altered mental status. On examination, he is drowsy and disoriented, with asterixis noted. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Initiation of lactulose therapy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient with hepatic encephalopathy. Lactulose is the first-line treatment for hepatic encephalopathy and works by reducing colonic pH, trapping ammonia as ammonium (NH4+), and promoting its excretion in the stool. It also acts as a laxative, reducing intestinal transit time and bacterial load, further decreasing ammonia production.

questions.text: A patient is identified as having a tumor in ileum, leading to urinary 5-HIAA being elevated. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Carcinoid syndrome has increased serotonin which convert into 5 HIAA.

questions.text: Which of the following tumor leads to hyperglycemia, necrolytic migratory erythema with depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hyperglycemia, necrolytic migratory erythema with depression is seen in glucagonoma.

questions.text: A female weighing 40 kg has a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Total sodium deficit = (140-120)x 0.5x40= 400.

questions.text: A patient having K+ levels of 2.3 meq/L. What would be most likely treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

If serum K is less than 2.5 meq/L then iv KCl replacement is given.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a constituent of treatment of severe hyperkalaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In acute treatment of hyperkalaemia iv calcium gluconate is given to stabilize cardiac membrane, iv insulin and beta agonist to lower serum potassium as they cause intracellular shifting of k. Dialysis is reserved for refractory cases.NaHCO3 given if associated metabolic acidosis is present.

questions.text: A middle aged male comes for a health check up in view of bone pains. On lab tests serum calcium was 14.0 mg/dl (high).Which ECG changes are expected
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ECG changes of hypercalcemia includes- short QT interval(most common),ST elevation due to development of Osborn waves(rare finding).

questions.text: A 40 year old male with alcohol abuse developed thiamine deficiency. You are suspecting Wernicke’s encephalopathy. The clinical features will include
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Wernicke’s Encephalopathy is seen in alcoholics due to chronic thiamine deficiency. The triad consists of Ophthalmoplegia, Mental confusion and Cerebellar ataxia. Peripheral neuropathy may be seen in addition to these typical findings. Treatment is Thiamine repletion.

questions.text: The potassium content in 500 ml of Ringer lactate solution is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The composition of Ringers Lactate solution is:

•	Na = 130 mmol/L

•	Cl = 109 mmol/L

•	Lactate = 28 mmol/L

•	K = 4 mmol/L

•	Ca = 1.5 mmol/L

Hence 500 ml will contain 2 mmol of K.

questions.text: What is the gauge of the pink colour iv cannula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The colour code of iv cannula are as follows:

questions.text: The ABG analysis of a patient is given as follows: pH=7.28, pCO2=80 mmHg, HCO3=28mEq. What can be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Low pH and high Paco2 is suggestive of respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: In case of severe multiple bouts of vomiting in a young person persisting for a few days. Which of the following Blood gas derangements will be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In vomiting there is loss of gastric HCl leading to metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: In case of severe multiple bouts of vomiting in a young person persisting for a few days. Which of the following Blood gas derangements will be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In vomiting there is loss of gastric HCl leading to metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with low backache. On work up he has anemia with elevated serum creatinine. X-ray of skull was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The classic radiographic appearance of multiple myeloma is that of multiple, small, well-circumscribed, lytic, punched-out, round lesions within the skull, spine, and pelvis. The pattern of lytic or punched-out radiolucent lesions on the skull have been described as resembling raindrops hitting a surface and splashing.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with complaints of tiredness. General physical examination findings are shown in the image were noticed. On lab workup his Hb= 8gm%. Which of the following is the best treatment approach for this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Spoon shaped nails are seen in iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presents with fatigue, restlessness, and macrocytic anemia. Serum methyl cobalamin level is normal. Which of the following should be now administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Macrocytosis is seen in folic acid deficiency and vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Gaisbock syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gaisbock syndrome is relative erythrocytosis due to decrease in plasma volume.

questions.text: Which is not included in qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

qSOFA score includes repiratory rate > 22/min,SBP<100 mmHg and GCS < 15.

questions.text: A patient developed shock after consumption of aspirin.You made a diagnosis of anaphylactic shock.What is the drug given for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

For anaphylactic shock drug of choice is intramuscular epinephrine 0.5 mg of 1:1000 dilution.Atropine is given for AV blocks and adenosine for PSVT.
